target_audience.primary_persona: Russian SME Finance/Accounting Teams managing corporate bank transactions and expenses, typically working with 1C ERP systems
secondary_personas: Business owners/founders needing expense visibility and approval control
Accountants reconciling bank statements with internal expense records
Finance managers analyzing spending patterns and cash flow
pain_points: Manual categorization of bank transactions is time-consuming and error-prone
Difficulty matching bank transactions to expense requests/invoices
Lack of real-time visibility into company spending by category
Disconnected data between bank statements and 1C ERP system
No centralized approval workflow for expense requests
Inconsistent categorization across different team members
goals: Automate bank transaction categorization using intelligent rules
Streamline expense request and approval workflow
Get real-time insights into spending patterns by category, counterparty, and time period
Synchronize data seamlessly with 1C ERP system
Reduce manual reconciliation effort between bank and internal records
target_audience.usage_context: Daily use by finance/accounting staff during business hours, with periodic heavy use during month-end/quarter-end reporting. Accessed via desktop web browser in office environment.

product_vision.one_liner: Intelligent bank transaction and expense management platform for Russian businesses using 1C ERP
product_vision.problem_statement: Russian SME finance teams spend excessive time manually categorizing bank transactions, reconciling with expense records, and generating reports. The disconnect between bank data and 1C ERP creates inefficiencies and errors.
product_vision.value_proposition: West Rashod automates bank transaction categorization using intelligent rules, seamlessly syncs with 1C ERP, and provides real-time analytics - reducing manual work by 70% and improving financial visibility.
success_metrics: Time spent on monthly reconciliation reduced by 50%+
User adoption rate (daily active users / total users)
Expense approval cycle time reduced by 40%

existing_features: User authentication (JWT-based with roles: Admin, Founder, Manager, Accountant, HR, User, Requester)
Bank transaction management (CRUD, import, bulk operations)
Categorization rules engine (by counterparty INN, name, business operation, keyword)
Expense request management with approval workflow (Draft, Pending, Approved, Rejected, Paid statuses)
Budget category management (hierarchical with OPEX/CAPEX types)
1C ERP synchronization (OData API - bank transactions, organizations, categories, contractors)
Analytics dashboard with charts (cash flow, category breakdown, counterparty analysis)
Transaction matching to expenses (manual and auto-match)
Task/background job management with progress tracking
known_gaps: Export functionality not fully implemented (TODO in analytics page)
No test coverage (tests directory is empty)
No audit trail/activity log visible in UI
No document attachment support for expenses
technical_debt: Empty test directory - no unit or integration tests
Some database models in venv test files appear in project index (indexing issue)
No documented API versioning strategy beyond v1

differentiators: Deep 1C ERP integration via OData (not a replacement, but a complement)
Modern web UI with real-time analytics
Expense approval workflow integrated with bank transactions
competitive_context.market_position: Specialized B2B SaaS tool for Russian SMEs already using 1C ERP, positioned as a modern analytics and workflow layer on top of bank/1C data rather than a full accounting replacement

technical: Requires 1C ERP with OData API access enabled
Must maintain compatibility with various 1C versions
Internal network access needed for 1C sync (based on IP configuration)
resources: Appears to be solo developer project (single contributor in git history)
Early-stage with limited development history (9 commits)
No dedicated QA or test infrastructure
dependencies: 1C ERP OData API availability and configuration
Bank transaction data quality from source systems
